Pro-life, pro-choice groups hold rallies at state Capitol Monday 






 By MetroNews Staff February 7, 2022 - 4:04 pm 

West Virginians for Life members held a rally in the Lower Rotunda of the state Capitol while there was a pro-choice demonstration above. - Jake Flatley/wvmetronews.comEmily Womeldorff (Middle), the Constituency Engagment Speical for Planned Parenthood holding a sign in the Upper Rotunda of the state Capitol on Monday. - Jake Flatley/wvmetronews.comJim Lewis, a retired episcopal priest, holds a pro-choice sign on Monday. - Jake Flatley/wvmetronews.com


CHARLESTON, W.Va. — As dozens of pro-life supporters rallied to end abortion in the Lower Rotunda of the state Capitol on Monday, those who support abortion access held a counter-demonstration in the Upper Rotunda.
Monday marked Pro-Life Day in the state Capitol as members of West Virginians for Life held a rally headlined by Rev. Mark E. Brennan, Bishop of the Diocese of Wheeling-Charleston, state Attorney General Patrick Morrisey, state Treasurer Riley Moore, Secretary of State Mac Warner and numerous GOP state lawmakers.
Brennan gave the invocation to the rally and said their movement cannot pit the woman against her child.
Mark Brennan
“We have to support both. That doesn’t mean supporting the killing of the child, that wouldn’t be pro-child. It means pro-woman, pro-mother and providing the kind of help that may persuade a woman for pursuing an abortion,” Brennan said to MetroNews.
Brennan also advocated that those in the pro-life movement need  not “write off those who have had abortions.” He spoke on his experience with Project Rachel, a ministry with those men and women involved in an abortion. He said there must be help given to women who need help with childcare.
“We have to show that we truly regard them as fellow human beings made in God’s image and likeness, and care for them as well,” Brennan said.
West Virginians for Life members joined Brennan in the state House of Delegates and state Senate galleries when sessions began.
Their rally focused on two pieces of legislation currently in the statehouse including The Unborn Child with Down Syndrome Protection and Education Act (SB468/HB4377) and Health Care Decisions Act Amendments (SB470).
Wanda Franz, president of West Virginians for Life told MetroNews her organization supports SB468. The piece of legislation, sponsored by Senator Patricia Rucker (R-Jefferson), is currently in the Senate Health and Human Resources Committee.
“The point is to put into law something that is against these eugenic abortions that are trying to eliminate the disease by eliminating the person who has the disease,” Franz said.
Franz said SB470 would correct sections of the WV Code, Sections 16-30-3 and 16-30-4, that have living will provisions and provide better-informed consent for people signing living wills.
Signs that supported abortion circled the Upper Rotunda as pro-abortion supporters circled the rally from a level above.
Margaret Chapman Pomponio, the CEO of West Virginia Free, was part of the demonstration in the Upper Rotunda and told MetroNews people should have access to unbiased healthcare in West Virginia.
Margaret Chapman Pomponio
“We’re calling on legislators to reject all of these abortion restrictions. West Virginia has already gone far enough and we need to protect basic healthcare and abortion is part of that,” Pomponio said.
Just one day into the 2022 regular legislative session, state lawmakers started moving a bill that would ban abortions at 15 weeks. The 15-week ban, HB 4004, passed the House Health Committee and is currently in the House Judiciary Committee.
Pomponio further called it an “extreme piece of legislation in this Capitol.”
“We’d like to see the legislature focus on increasing access to healthcare and education rather than these regressive attempts to make abortion illegal and out of reach for West Virginians,” she said.
Emily Womeldorff, the Constituency Engagement Special for Planned Parenthood held a sign with the Women’s Health Center that said “No Abortion Bans.”
She shared the same feelings as Pompino on recent legislation moving through the dome. Womeldorff noted that since 2014, there have been abortion bans introduced every year.
“We are not in the minority in our feelings. Enough is enough with the abortion bans that are medically unnecessary and restrict access for people in the state who need a healthcare service,” Womeldorff said.
Womeldorff was vocal in support of HB 4382: Relating to preserving a patient’s right to abortion. Monongalia County Delegates Danielle Walker and Evan Hansen introduced the legislation on Jan. 29.
“It repeals numerous provisions in state code that restrict a patient’s right to abortion,” Hansen said during the presser on Jan. 29. “So, we would be operating through what’s allowed through Roe v. Wade.”
The Roe v. Wade court decision said women have the right to choose to have an abortion without excessive government restriction. MetroNews previously reported that current West Virginia law requires a woman to receive counseling, a 24-hour wait and parental notification. The procedure cannot be performed after 20 weeks and can only be funded with public money under extreme circumstances.
